questions.question: What is an example of Misconduct? (Page 15)
options: An agent failed to fully assess a client’s needs and objectives and neglected to advise the client of changes to the insurance plan as a consequence of a medical condition
An agent provided a copy of a client’s insurance policy to other customers as an example of the product being offered
An agent must act in an honest, courteous, and respectful manner when dealing with other agents
A and B

questions.question: What is a requirement when dealing with clients, an agent must? (Page 14)
options: Protect the client’s interests and privacy
Appropriately evaluate the client’s needs
Disclose all material information
All of the above

questions.question: The exercise of Good Faith by certificate holders in the practice of insurance is essential to public confidence in the industry. To whom does the agent owe good faith? (Page 9)
options: Insurers, insureds, fellow agents, the general public
Insurers, insureds, fellow agents, regulatory bodies, their employer
Insurers, insureds, fellow agents, regulatory bodies, and the public
All of the above

questions.question: Which statement is FALSE in regard to dealing with clients as an Agent? (Page 14)
options: Charge the client a mandatory undisclosed fee for providing services to correctly select an appropriate insurance policy based on their risk
Protect the client’s interests and privacy
Appropriately evaluate the client’s needs
Disclose all material information

questions.question: Engaging in misleading advertising breaches which codes? (Pages 15 and 18)
options: Dealing with the public, competence
Dealing with the agent, dealing with the client
Dealing with the public, dealing with the client
Dealing with the AIC, compliance to the government

questions.question: Bob and the local insurance agent, Tim, are close friends. They start a mechanics shop together. Tim only places a Named Perils Commercial Property Policy to keep costs low and plans to add coverage later. Which statement is most correct about Tim’s actions?
options: Tim breached the Financial Integrity Code as he is not properly handling business operations
Tim breached the Dealing with Clients Code as he is in a conflict of interest
Tim breached the Competence Code as he intentionally withheld information from the insurer
Tim breached the Dealing with Insurers Code as he falsified information to the insurer
B and D
B and C

questions.question: What is the Principle of Financial Integrity? (Page 13)
options: Clients and insurers entrust money, property, and financial instruments to agents, and integrity is essential to the practice
An agent must properly safeguard and account for money and property entrusted to them and promptly deliver it
Insurers rely on the agent’s honesty and competence to meet contractual duties
All of the above

questions.question: Which of the following is considered an Agent under the Code of Conduct? (Page 6)
options: A person authorized by certification to transact insurance business whose licence is sponsored by an insurer
An individual that holds a certificate of authority to transact insurance business as defined in the Insurance Act
A representative of an insurance company paid as an underwriter
An individual who sells insurance on behalf of an agency approved by AIC, GIC, and IBAA

questions.question: Kyle has been in the business for 40 years. During COVID-19, he contacts clients by phone and oversells insurance while they are fearful. This breaches which section of the Code of Conduct? (Pages 2–3)
options: Incompetence in dealing with the public
Lack of financial integrity in dealing with clients
Breaching confidentiality in dealing with clients
Mismanagement of customer funds for personal gain

questions.question: You are encouraged by an insurer to place one more policy to qualify for a vacation, even though the insurer does not offer the best product for the client. This is an issue of competency and an example of: (Page 12)
options: Being persuaded by personal gain
Violating the trust of the client
Misconduct
All of the above

questions.question: Alberta Insurance Council provides administrative and investigative support to which councils? (Page 5)
options: Alberta Insurance Council, General Insurance Council, Accident & Sickness Council
Life Insurance Council, General Insurance Council, Adjusters Council
Life Insurance Council, Accident & Sickness Council, Adjusters Council
Alberta Insurance Council, General Insurance Council, Adjusters Insurance Council

questions.question: Where an agent collects or receives funds on behalf of an insurer, they must: (Page 13)
options: Not use the funds for purposes other than those described in the agreement
Pay the insurer all funds collected, less authorized deductions
Pay clients all funds due to them
All of the above

questions.question: Under what circumstances in the Code of Conduct would you be able to breach client confidentiality? (Page 15)
options: When the client’s mother calls to inquire about their policy
When parents give consent to disclose information to a third party
When an investigator, RCMP, or lawyer contacts the office
When required by criminal law during an investigation

questions.question: Ted requests cancellation of a paid policy to apply the premium against an outstanding debt. This misconduct falls under which category of the Code of Conduct? (Page 8)
options: Good Faith
Competence
Dealing with clients
Trustworthiness

questions.question: The agent must carry on the business of insurance in good faith. To whom does the agent owe this duty? (Page 9)
options: Insurers, insureds, fellow agents
The agent acts solely for the client
The agent acts solely for the insurer
Insurers, insureds, fellow agents, regulatory bodies, and the public

questions.question: A “conflict of interest” position means a situation where an intermediary:
options: Is charging an excessive rate of interest on a payment plan
Is acting in the best interests of the client and other stakeholders
Has an incentive to act other than in the best interest of the client
Commits a civil wrong other than a breach of contract
